You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: such reduction would need Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: however, wage and other data indicate that there is still slack in the labour market.\n                "}]

   \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: as those effects wear off, cpi inflation may edge up again before settling around the 2% target next year.\n                "}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence provides a neutral forecast of inflation settling around the 2% target without implying any policy action or bias."
}

\\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in the context of a label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: short-term inflation expectations remain elevated.\n                "}]

changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the banks current base case projection shows the output gap closing later than was anticipated in october, around the end of 2017.\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence implies a slower-than-expected closing of the output gap, which may warrant continued monetary stimulus to support economic growth."
}

sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the necessary efforts to Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: global financial conditions have tightened and volatility has increased.\n                "}]

changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: total cpi inflation in canada has been around 1 per cent in recent months, reflecting year-over-year price declines for consumer energy products.\n                "}]

reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation the rest of the way back to 2% could prove to be more difficult because inflation expectations are coming down slowly, service price inflation and wage growth remain elevated, and corporate pricing behaviour has yet to normalize.\n                "}]
2025-05-03 17:43:05,060 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence highlights concerns about inflation expectations, elevated wage growth, and corporate pricing behavior, suggesting that inflation may not easily return to the 2% target, which could lead to tightening policies."
}

label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the global economy Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: nevertheless, indicators of demand should start to show renewed momentum in early 2019, leading to above-potential growth of 2.1 per cent in 2020.\n                "}]

pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the bank of canada today held its target for the overnight rate at the effective lower bound of  percent, with the bank rate at  percent and the deposit rate at  percent.\n                "}]
