action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: together with a moderation label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: this sequence will be bolstered by the considerable easing in financial conditions that has occurred and by improving u.s. demand.\n                "}]

changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: shelter costs remain the biggest contributor to above-target inflation.\n                "}]

sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the bank expects the Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: global financial conditions remain accommodative.\n                "}]

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without financial vulnerabilities are elevated and rising, particularly in the greater vancouver and toronto areas.\n                "}]

"label": "neutral",

label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the global economic label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: after a weak first half, the us economy in particular is strengthening: solid consumption is being underpinned by strong employment growth and robust consumer confidence.\n                "}]

decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: while employment growth has remained firm, indicators still point to significant slack in the labour market.\n                "}]

changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: growth in the euro area You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the lower outlook for canadian growth has increased the downside risks to inflation.\n                "}]

Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: because of high debt levels, household spending is likely more sensitive to interest rates than in the past.\n                "}]

workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: however, with underlying inflation persisting, central banks continue to be vigilant.\n                "}]

sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: supported by central bank actions and by positive policy developments in europe, global financial conditions are more stimulative.\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence implies that global financial conditions are becoming more stimulative due to central bank actions and positive policy developments, suggesting an accommodative stance."
}
